intro: Coronopus patagonicus, commonly known as the Patagonian coronopus, is a flowering plant native to the southern regions of South America. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other well-known flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that are typically white or pale purple in color. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky or sandy soils. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and vulnerable species.
